results.title: Remembering
results.creator_credit: Laura Brearley, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Laura Brearley’s dear friend died of cancer, Brearley took solace in her art, her music and remembering. In doing this, Brearley gave the gift of comfort to many others.

results.title: The Gift
results.creator_credit: Jodine Stodart, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 2005, Jodine Stodart travelled to Oxfam Australia to India. It was there that she met a unique lady, not much older than herself, that would leave a lasting impression on the young traveller.

results.title: Three cows
results.creator_credit: Gavin Bannerman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Gavin Bannerman grew up on a farm out of Brisbane. The Bannermans had a deal with the local butcher for their cattle and every season they would either have a fridge full of meat or a tidy sum. One day, they decided to name their cows.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavin Bannerman, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 - Indigo
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo was broadcast as the sixth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Tekno Mandala (Adem Jaffers), Force Fed (Stuart McCormick & Michael Brand), Magnetic Head Circuit (Chubba, Matt Bastard, Peter Randall), Antartica, Future, Wake up Return 2 Heart, Rave Safe Info (Melissa Dent & Michael Arnold), Air Fiction (Andy Taylor), Steve Law (Zen Paradox), Tom Cia, Derek ‘Chill’ Shiel and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 6 – Indigo is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.headline_credit: Australia, Fiji, New Caledonia and New Zealand, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film shows a cruise from Sydney Harbour to possibly New Caledonia, Fiji and New Zealand, including scenic views, time with friends’ son and off the cruise ship.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:34:00 leaving Sydney Harbour in cruise ship; views of the Opera House and the Harbour
00:01:36:00 views from lookout wth friends, looking over a small city
00:04:27:00 a day trip from cruise to island, maybe New Caledonia, due to circular style of grass hut
00:05:26:00 ring volleyball game on cruise ship
00:06:43:00 views from cruise ship coming into port at Nadi, Fiji
00:08:26:00 filmmaker’s wife Evelyn with local family, and swimming at the beach
00:10:08:00 cruise ship coming into port, marching band farewells/welcomes passengers
00:11:50:00 Rainbow Springs sign, Rotorua, NZ
00:12:06:00 trout farm at Rainbow Springs Nature Park
00:13:42:00 hot springs in New Zealand
0014:27:00 cruise ship coming back into Sydney harbour, views of cliffs surrounding Sydney Harbour

results.title: [Alexander Sinclair Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.headline_credit: Australia and Papua New Guinea, c. 1970s
results.brief_description:
Alexander Sinclair (21 October 1918 – 3 May 1998) was an amateur filmmaker who lived in Papua New Guinea with his wife Evelyn Sinclair for approximately 20 years from 1959 onwards. They lived in Port Moresby for three years, followed by Goroka. He made home movies of life in Papua New Guinea and travels with Evelyn and their friends to the UK, the Netherlands, USA, Melbourne and Sydney throughout the 1960s and 1970s.

The collection of home movies, originally made on Super 8mm film, was donated to ACMI by their daughter Elizabeth Robbins.

This film is shot in New Guinea and features the filmmaker’s family and friends, locals, people gathering in vast numbers for celebrations in various traditional dress, Chinese dragon display, scenic views, and road safety issues. Most likely filmed around Goroka, as the filmmaker lived mainly in Goroka.

Selected Highlights List (time codes from Access Overscan)
00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden
00:03:23:00 car wreck being towed away and off the road
00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

00:00:00:00 opens with footage shot around the filmmaker’s home; we see a sign with his name, Alex Sinclair, out the front of the white house; family and friends around the garden

00:04:50:00 filmmaker and friends have a picnic on top of a hill. Local kids come to watch and pose for the camera.
00:05:55:00 along a river, feeding fish with friends, and a nearby wild bird sanctuary or zoo
00:07:29:00 Missionary Aviation Fellowship aircraft at airfield
00:08:32:00 stunning mountain views
00:10:14:00 lunch with friends at a restaurant near the bay
00:11:24:00 traditional Chinese Dragon dance and fire crackers along a town street
00:12:35:00 Lions Club road safety campaign displaying cars salvaged from crashes
00:13:46:00 celebrations of people in traditional dress from various districts; remarkable head dresses and masks made from mud or clay, alongside those made from feathers and woven materials, dancing, building hut demonstrations
00:14:36:00 more truck accidents; local kids come to see, then dance and entertain the filmmaker and friends
00:15:46:00 more stunning views of mountains
00:16:14:00 more ceremonial gatherings of various people and audiences

results.title: Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue
results.brief_description:
Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 – Blue was broadcast as the fifth of eight in an episodic series on Channel 31 in Melbourne. This format allowed for the creation of tighter, curated segments for broadcast instead of the impromptu, marathon-like events of the previous Cyberthons.

As well as electronic music, art, remixed footage (from previous Cyberthon events), guerrilla style music videos, drug and rave safe promotions, experimental performances and short films, global participation was also encouraged via online production meetings. As Cyberthon curator Adem Jaffers said “Cyberthon had become a public TV ‘Access Show’ nested within a public TV ‘Access Channel’ [which was] quite unique really!”

A selection of artists: Adem Jaffers (Tekno Mandala), Space Between the Gaps (Paul Gafney), Dale Nasonand Kim Bounds (abcTVxyz), Dale Nason and Troy Innocent (Cyber Dada), 1x4x9 (Braden Schlager & Miles du Heaume), Video Graffiti (Andrew Nelson), ABCTVXYZ, Surfis (Dom Owen and Peter Bourke), Don’t Shoot the Messenger (Steve Middleton) and The Visitor (Andrew Till).

Cyberthon V: Spectrum 5 - Blue is part of the Cyberthon Archive generously donated to ACMI by Adem Jaffers.

results.title: Don't Shoot the Messenger
results.brief_description: “Visuals recorded live at a digital meditation in cyberspace performed during the Mayday dance party 1993. A series of computers and cameras were interconnected, manipulated realtime and projected.” Sourced from VHS cover slip for Don’t Shoot the Messenger

results.title: Man proposes, God disposes
results.creator_credit: Sophia Selvakumar, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When Sophia Selvakumar first came to Australia, she missed her family so terribly she returned to India after 70 days. Eventually, she returned to Australia and set about making this country her new home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sophia Selvakumar, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
